snippet: Nearly three months after people in the city of Aleppo poured into a hospital with symptoms of a chemical weapons attack, it remains hard to say for certain what happened — and who is responsible.
abstract: Antakya Memo; unexplained March 2012 incident in Aleppo, Syria, in which people poured into a hospital with symptoms of a nerve gas attack, highlights uncertainty over whether chemical weapons are being used in Syria and who is responsible.

byline.contributor: Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington, and Karam Shoumali from Antakya.

lead_paragraph: Nearly three months after people in the city of Aleppo poured into a hospital with symptoms of a chemical weapons attack, it remains hard to say for certain what happened — and who is responsible.

headline.seo: Still More Questions Than Answers on Nerve Gas in Syria
headline.main: Still More Questions Than Answers on Nerve Gas in Syria
headline.print_headline: Still More Questions Than Answers On Nerve Gas in Syria
